name: The OG Manhattan
description: Hit the most iconic Manhattan skate spots in one legendary day — from the Brooklyn Banks to Tompkins, through LES and finishing at Astor Place. This is the route every NYC skater should ride at least once.

stops.activity: Start at the legendary Brooklyn Banks — warm up on the marble ledges and soak in the history of NYC skating's spiritual home.
stops.transitToNext: Skate north on Park Row, then east on Delancey — about 15 min ride through the Lower East Side.

stops.activity: Session the LES Skatepark's smooth concrete bowls and street section. Great for all levels with plenty of features.
stops.transitToNext: Head north on Essex/Allen, then east on Houston — quick 10 min push to Tompkins.

stops.activity: Cruise through the park and hit the famous Tompkins benches and ledges. Grab a slice on Ave A while you're at it.
stops.transitToNext: Skate west on St Marks Place — 10 min ride straight to Astor Place.

stops.activity: Finish at the Astor Place cube — smooth ground, ledges everywhere, and prime people-watching. Iconic way to end the day.

name: Brooklyn Bridge to Banks
description: Cross the Brooklyn Bridge on your board, hit the Banks, then loop through downtown Manhattan's best street spots. Touristy? Maybe. Epic? Absolutely.

stops.activity: Start in DUMBO — session the smooth waterfront plaza with the Manhattan Bridge framing every trick. Perfect warm-up spot.
stops.transitToNext: Push up to the Brooklyn Bridge bike/pedestrian path — 20 min crossing (watch for tourists!).

stops.activity: Drop off the bridge straight into the Banks. The brick-to-marble transitions here are unlike anything else in the city.
stops.transitToNext: Head south on Broadway — 10 min push through the Financial District.

stops.activity: Federal Plaza's massive open area with smooth ground and long granite ledges. Perfect for lines and flatground.

name: Williamsburg to Bushwick
description: Brooklyn's creative corridor — from McCarren Park's modern skatepark through the street art of Bushwick to the DIY energy of Cooper Park. This route is pure Brooklyn.

stops.activity: Start at McCarren's excellent concrete park — bowls, rails, ledges, and a chill local scene. Great place to warm up.
stops.transitToNext: Skate south on Bedford Ave, then east on Metropolitan — 15 min through the heart of Williamsburg.

stops.activity: Cooper Park's mini ramp and flat area — neighborhood park vibe with surprisingly good features.
stops.transitToNext: Continue east on Maspeth Ave into Bushwick — 10 min ride through murals and street art.

stops.activity: End at the DIY spot — raw, creative, and unapologetically Brooklyn. Bring your own wax and good vibes.

name: Queens Quest
description: Explore Queens' diverse skate scene — from Flushing Meadows' world-class park to the beachfront vibes of Rockaway. This borough has way more than people think.

stops.activity: Start at the Flushing Meadows Skatepark — warm up in the bowl and street section with the Unisphere watching over you.
stops.transitToNext: Skate through the park, then hop the Q65 bus to the Maloof park — about 15 min.

stops.activity: Session the Maloof Skatepark's snake run and deep bowl. This is competition-level terrain — push yourself.
stops.transitToNext: 7 train from Flushing to Jackson Heights, then E/F to Far Rockaway — about 50 min total.

stops.activity: End at the beach. Session the Far Rockaway park, then reward yourself with ocean waves and a cold drink.
If you've got gas left, cruise to the Rockaway Beach park for a sunset session steps from the Atlantic.

name: Beach Day
description: Sun, sand, and skateboarding — hit the coastal parks from Brooklyn to Queens. Pack sunscreen and a towel.

stops.activity: Start at Coney Island — morning session at the park, then grab a Nathan's hot dog for fuel.
stops.transitToNext: Take the boardwalk east or hop the Q35 bus — about 40 min to the Rockaways.

stops.activity: Rockaway Beach park with ocean breeze. Take a surf break if you brought a board.
stops.transitToNext: Skate east along the boardwalk — 20 min ride.

stops.activity: End the day at Far Rockaway. Mellow park, perfect for tired legs.

name: Rainy Day Options
description: When it's pouring, you don't stop skating — you get creative. Hit the covered spots and DIY havens that work in the wet.

stops.activity: Start at South Beach DIY — the overpass keeps you dry. Raw concrete obstacles and full coverage.
stops.transitToNext: SIR to St. George, then ferry to Manhattan, subway to Brooklyn — about 1 hr.

stops.activity: The Williamsburg Bridge underpass stays dry. Crusty banks and ledges — bring your A-game.
stops.transitToNext: J train to Myrtle-Broadway — 15 min.

stops.activity: Finish at the Bed-Stuy DIY under the J/M tracks. Covered, creative, and always evolving.

name: The Full Borough Blitz
description: The ultimate NYC skate marathon — hit all five boroughs in one epic day. This is a full-day commitment and a badge of honor.

stops.activity: Start early on Staten Island. Warm up at Stapleton before catching the ferry.
stops.transitToNext: Walk to St. George terminal, take the Staten Island Ferry — 25 min, free, iconic views.

stops.activity: Ferry lands in Manhattan — head straight to the Brooklyn Banks. Pay your respects to the most legendary spot in NYC.
stops.transitToNext: Skate across the Brooklyn Bridge — 20 min and unforgettable.

stops.activity: Session McCarren in Williamsburg. Grab lunch on Bedford Ave.
stops.transitToNext: G train to Court Square, transfer to 7 train to Flushing — about 40 min.

stops.activity: Queens stop — Flushing Meadows park. Solid features with the Unisphere backdrop.
stops.transitToNext: 7 train back to Manhattan, transfer to 4 train to the Bronx — about 45 min.

stops.activity: Finish in the Bronx at Mullaly — the OG Bronx park. You just skated all five boroughs. Legend.

name: Culture & Kickflips
description: NYC isn't just about spots — it's about the culture around them. This route pairs great skate spots with museums, galleries, and cultural landmarks.

stops.activity: Start with a morning session on the marble benches of Columbus Park. Then explore Chinatown — grab dim sum for fuel.
stops.transitToNext: Skate north on Centre St to SoHo — 15 min cruise through the galleries.

stops.activity: Hit Federal Plaza's iconic marble ledges. Supreme's original Lafayette St shop is right around the corner — peek in.
stops.transitToNext: Push north through NoHo to Astor Place — easy 10 min ride.

stops.activity: Session the ultra-smooth Astor Place plaza. The Cube sculpture has been a skater meeting point for decades.
stops.transitToNext: Skate north on Broadway, cut through Union Square — 15 min to Chelsea.

stops.activity: End at Chelsea Piers skatepark overlooking the Hudson. Hit the nearby Chelsea galleries if you've got energy left.
